Clinical Note:

Patient: Yuriko Cole
NHS Number: 9592380554
Date of Birth: May 9, 2004

Diagnosis: Perennial allergic rhinitis with seasonal variation. The patient presents with symptoms of sneezing, congestion, and runny nose throughout the year, with exacerbation during peak pollen seasons. History of previous allergies and family history of atopic conditions support this diagnosis. Recommendations: Prescribe allergen-blocking medication and advise patient on avoidance measures during peak pollen seasons. Monitor symptoms and adjust treatment as needed.

Clinical Note for Patient Tiera Crooks:

Patient is a 28-year-old female who presents today with a 6-day history of persistent headache and blurred vision. She reports that the headaches are severe, recurring daily, and worsened by light and noise. The patient has a history of chronic intractable migraine without aura, which started approximately one year ago. No other symptoms or signs are noted. Recommendations: Continue propranolol 40mg PO q8hr and increase if necessary. Consider escalating to secondary care if pain is not adequately controlled.

Clinical Note:

Patient: Antoine Thiel
NHS Number: 4936161268
Date of Birth: October 10, 2006

Presenting Complaints:
Acute viral pharyngitis (disorder)

Chief Complaint: Sore throat and fever for the past 3 days.

History of Present Illness: Developed sore throat and fever after a cold exposure 3 days ago. No significant medical history or allergies.

Physical Examination: Temperature: 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure: 120/80 mmHg, respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation: 98% on room air. Tender anterior cervical lymph nodes.

Diagnosis: Acute viral pharyngitis (disorder)

Plan: Prescribe acetaminophen PO 325 mg every 4-6 hours as needed for pain and fever reduction, and recommend plenty of fluids to stay hydrated. Monitor patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

Note: This is just an example clinical note and should not be used in place of a real medical diagnosis or treatment plan.

Clinical Note:
Patient: Sammie Roberts
NHS Number: 0385466099
Date of Birth: May 19, 2023

Chief Complaint: Sinus pressure and congestion for the past week.

History of Present Illness: The patient presents with a one-week history of sinus pressure and congestion. She reports difficulty breathing through her nose and has experienced postnasal drip. Her symptoms have been worsening over the past few days, despite using over-the-counter decongestants.

Physical Examination: On examination, the patient's nasal cavities are congested, with clear mucus present. There is minimal nasal wheezing, and her chest auscultation reveals no abnormal sounds.

Diagnosis: Viral sinusitis (disorder)

Plan: Prescribe antiviral medication and recommend steam inhalation to help alleviate symptoms. Instruct the patient to avoid picking her nose and to keep her head elevated while sleeping to reduce congestion.

Clinical Note:

Patient Name: Donnell Keeling
NHS Number: 0314071555
Date of Birth: July 31, 2007

Presenting Complaint: Acute bronchitis (disorder)

Chief Concerns: Cough, fever, chest tightness, shortness of breath

Relevant History: Recent viral infection, exposure to secondhand smoke

Physical Examination: Tachycardia, tachypnea, wheezing sounds on lung examination

Laboratory Results: Normal complete blood count (CBC), elevated inflammatory markers (CRP and ESR)

Impression: Acute bronchitis (disorder) likely caused by viral infection, exacerbated by secondhand smoke exposure. Treatment plan includes antibiotics for potential bacterial superinfection, corticosteroids for inflammation reduction, and smoking cessation counseling.

Clinical Note:
Patient Name: Keven Feil
NHS Number: 9752103847
Date of Birth: January 17, 1991

Chief Complaint:
The patient presents with a 3-day history of nasal congestion, facial pain, and loss of sense of smell. The symptoms have been worsening over the past 24 hours, with no relief from over-the-counter medications.

History of Present Illness:
The patient reports a gradual onset of symptoms, starting with a mild cough and congestion that has progressed to severe nasal congestion, facial pain, and loss of sense of smell. The patient has no history of respiratory disease or recent travel.

Physical Examination:
On examination, the patient's nose is significantly congested with thick, yellowish discharge. There is tenderness to palpation over the cheekbones and forehead, and the patient reports facial pain. The patient's sense of smell is severely impaired.

Diagnosis: Viral sinusitis (disorder)

Plan:
The patient will be prescribed a 5-day course of antiviral medication and advised to continue nasal decongestants as needed. The patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment in 3 days to assess symptom resolution.

Clinical Note:

Patient: Tracey Bechtelar
NHS Number: 1689680024
Date of Birth: March 19, 2020

Presenting Complaint: Viral sinusitis (disorder)

Chief Concerns: Nasal congestion, facial pain, postnasal drip, cough.

Relevant History: Acute onset of symptoms over the past 3 days. No previous history of sinusitis.

Physical Examination: Nasal endoscopy reveals nasal congestion and turbinate hypertrophy. Bilateral conjunctival injection and preauricular lymphadenopathy are noted.

Diagnosis: Viral sinusitis (disorder)

Plan: Oral antiviral medication as prescribed, steam inhalation, and nasal decongestants as needed. Monitor patient for signs of worsening symptoms or complications.
